author: Christopher Russell
title: OZ Minerals welcomes KKR stake buy
text:
COPPER miner OZ Minerals has welcomed private investors KKR taking a significant stake in the company.
The news sent OZ Minerals share price soaring more than 19 per cent to close at $3.95 yesterday, but the company was trading 3 per cent lower at 11am AEST today.
“We welcome KKR as a shareholder,” OZ Minerals chairman Neil Hamilton said.
“It’s pleasing that they have recognised the underlying value of OZ Minerals and chosen to be part of our exciting future.”
Now Adelaide-based, OZ Minerals owns the Prominent Hill mine and Carrapateena project in South Australia.
KKR — Kohlberg Kravis Roberts — said its subsidiaries and associated companies had been buying OZ shares on market this week before clinching a cash-settled equity swap via Deutsche Bank’s London office to reach its target.
“We think that OZ Minerals is a good company that was undervalued in the public markets when we made our investment,” KKR Asia Pacific public affairs manager Steven Okun said. “We thought it was a good time to accumulate exposure to OZ Minerals shares given the environment.
“We went out seeking an interest in 10 per cent of the stock at a certain price and were successful in doing so.”
KKR did not give any further public comment on whether it would sit tight, buy more stock, launch a takeover or seek influence on OZ such as taking a board seat. However, some reports indicated it had no currently intention to mount a takeover.
KKR told the Australian Securities Exchange it had become a substantial shareholder and said it would lodge further notices. These are expected to give greater clarity to the exact size of its stake but at 10 per cent it will have overtaken institutional investors NAB, Blackrock, JCP Investment Partners, Dimensional and Vinva which hold between 5 per cent and 8 per cent each.
Deutsche Bank analyst Brett McKay said the move by KKR was “a shot in the arm” for the resources sector where shares have been burdened by low commodity prices.
“Prominent Hill looks to be over the worst of its problems — the waste stripping that’s been going on for a number of years,” he said.
“There is a decent free cashflow stream that’s apparent over the next few years.
“The company has a good balance sheet, a lot of cash, no debt — so I’d guess a combination of those things is what’s attracted private equity to it.”
OZ’s share price has been hit by the fall in copper in US dollar terms, especially since May this year. However, copper has picked up in the past few days and in Australian dollar terms has been steady most of the past two years because of the effect of the exchange rate.
